Chapter: Hi, my name is Ostap and here is my story.
Description:
Linkedin    Instagram    Facebook   Download Resume

I have been fortunate enough to live and work in various places and I will briefly describe my experience below.
Currently I am based in the city of Manchester where I have just completed my master's in GIS.

I was born in a small, beautiful town in Western Ukraine, which is probably the most 'Ukrainian' town in the country.
The place craved democracy, and freedom and, since the 1990s, had a massive desire to join the EU.
Here is where my basic values were formed, where I met my first friends, tried my first work, and read my first books.
Growing up in Ternopil, I learned how to play the violin and survive in the wild. Both of those skills became handy later, even though I never expected them to be useful.

Media Credit: Source: Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv
Description:
I moved to the capital when I was 17 to study history at Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv .
It was the best university in the country, and I was granted a scholarship because I was among a handful of people who scored 200 out of 200 on the national exam. That was probably my first significant achievement, and I worked hard for it.
Back then, just like millions of young people worldwide, I had little idea what I wanted to do with my life, and I think history attracted me because I always liked stories. I am happy about it, as studying at Kyiv University certainly contributed to my development.
I also thought of studying geography, which I was always good at, but I did not see how I could apply it in the future. Back then, I knew nothing of GIS, which was a gap in my schooling.
External independent testing results

It was in Kyiv, where I had my first job. During the summer break, I was a waiter at a nightclub.
It was not the most pleasant job, but it taught me a lot. That job made me more independent and responsible, and it contributed to developing my communication skills and allowed me to understand better what kind of person I want to be.
It was also my first time working in a different language environment. Everyone spoke Russian in that part of the town, and I had to adopt it for work. It was not easy, but it was worthwhile.
I remember the managers asked me to learn the menu, and the next day they were astonished that I knew it by heart. They said that nobody had ever done it in that place. I felt good about it.

During my student years, I also hiked a lot. Climbing a mountain is a challenging undertaking, and it requires self-control and determination. However, it is also rewarding as it provides a sense of achievement. My friends and I organised numerous hikes in Carpathian and Crimean Mountains. Needless to say, it was before 2014.
It was a summer job for me too. I lead groups of people into wilder parts of the mountains. Often these groups included foreigners, and it was my first working experience in English.

AIESEC is an international youth-run NGO which became a big part of my life in October 2012. AIESEC contributed massively to the development of my values and my leadership skills. In spring 2013, I was a team leader of five people with whom we organised various events for foreign interns in Ukraine. Our team also helped with logistics, as Kyiv was a hub from where many AIESECers moved to different parts of the country.
I still have close relations with my team members and numerous friends from as distant places as Brazil and New Zealand, thanks to my volunteering in AIESEC Kyiv.

AIESEC inspired me to try something new and step out of my comfort zone. I wanted to have the experience I saw many of my foreign friends had in Kyiv. I wanted to experience life and work in a place where the culture and the environment were completely different from anything I knew before.
Because of this desire, I AIESEC inspired me to try something new and step out of my comfort zone. I wanted to have the experience I saw many of my foreign friends had in Kyiv. I wanted to experience life and work in a place where the culture and the environment were completely different from anything I knew before.
Because of this desire, I applied for an interesting AIESEC environmental program in Guangzhou. I was accepted, and my fantastic China experience began.
For nearly half a year, I worked with a group of international volunteers. Together we studied the environmental situation in the Pearl River Delta region and prepared educational presentations. We helped high school and university students to develop the knowledge, skills, and attitudes to live more sustainably and encouraged actions in accordance with the UN 17 Sustainable Development Goals.

My parents ran a carpentry business back home. As I was living in probably the most economically active area in the world, I started exploring various business ideas. The most successful of those happened to be bamboo flooring. I travelled to the wholesale markets in Guangzhou, Foshan, Dongguan, Shenzhen, etc. and made deals with local business people buying bamboo floorings from them. I arranged the shipments of containers to Ukraine and Poland, where my parents and their business partners distributed the goods.

I moved to Beijing in September 2015 as I wanted to continue my education. I was accepted for a two-year program at the newly created Business School of Beijing Foreign Studies University. There were many foreign professors from as diverse places as Singapore and Lancaster.
During this program, I learned a great deal about various business practices in China and abroad and improved my communication and marketing skills. Because of the numerous exchange programs with the universities in Europe and North America every semester, I made new friends who often were extraordinary people who chose to come to China instead of an 'easy exchange' in a developed country.
I had an active and exciting student life. I organised a successful "Sitning" singing party for over thirty students and a speed-dating event on the university's campus.

I also led a group of students to the Taihang Mountains west of Beijing. Those were great adventures, during which I met my future wife, Veronika. Together we climbed the tallest mountain in Beijing municipality Linshan, and a beautiful Tangshang summit called Xiao Wutaishan. I have great memories of those times.

As part of my business studies, I went to the city of Foshan in Guangdong province. Here, together with my classmates, I visited various enterprises and wrote a business plan for a company that produced soft drinks. I presented this plan before company representatives.

During my master's, I taught English as a foreign language on the weekends as I needed to fund my education. I mainly taught high school students, and it was a good experience as it allowed me to improve my presentation skills and better understand the younger Chinese generation.

After I had completed my degree, I joined GSafety, one of the member companies of Tsinghua Holdings and a research spin-off of the Institute of Public Safety Research of Tsinghua University. The company focused on public safety and emergency management and rapidly expanded its business abroad. Working at GSafety was an excellent opportunity as I tried myself in different roles and worked on numerous projects. It was also a chance to experience the work at a major Chinese company with the opportunity to develop myself at Tsinghua University (downloadable Summer School certificate), to which GSafety was affiliated.

Chapter: Hefei Institute for Public Safety Research, Anhui province
Description: Hefei Institute for Public Safety Research, Tsinghua University, closely cooperated with GSafety. I visited it countless times, learning about the company's available emergency management technologies and presenting ready-made solutions to potential clients from abroad. My first solution presentation experience was for the delegation from Kazakhstan in February 2018. That was the only time I presented in Russian; all the other presentations were done in English, which was the company's working language alongside Chinese.

My first business trip abroad was to Spain in December 2018. At that time, Madrid’s Santiago Bernabeu stadium was preparing for renovations, and at GSafety we worked very hard to design a stadium fire evacuation solution. As the project was for Real Madrid’s home stadium, it was highly competitive, and we did not win the bid. However, for me, it was a great experience working on and presenting a complex technical solution before high-standing officials.

My next project was in Beirut, where we cooperated with one of Lebanon's major public safety companies. It was a very ambitious project that was meant to ensure the city's preparedness for various natural disasters and emergencies. During this trip, I presented a "smart Beirut" solution before the minister of the interior of Lebanon.

Probably the most memorable and positively impactful projects I worked on was in Sierra Leone. I spent around a month in a country doing an on-field assessment. The project aimed to assess and report the state of school infrastructure in the city. The Sierra Leonean government wanted to provide tablet computers to every school in the capital. I personally visited numerous schools to inspect the infrastructure's conditions and the access to electricity. Unsurprisingly most schools that had poor infrastructure were located in informal settlements. These schools required special attention; however, there was little data related to electricity grids in the informal settlements, and even their extent and population were unclear.
Relying on my on-field inspection and various available spatial data, I used ArcGIS software to analyse and map the precise extent of Freetown's informal settlements and the schools that were in most need of direct assistance. I presented my report before senior management and government officials, which directly influenced the distribution of the project's resources. Later, at the University of Manchester, I used these findings as the basis for one of my assessments. The resulting paper explains my reasoning and demonstrates my ability to use ArcGIS software to solve complex spatial problems.
Another very interesting project was in East Kalimantan, Indonesia. I worked on projects related to mine rehabilitation in Indonesia and
Amazon rainforest protection in Brazil.

I worked on numerous other projects which inspired my interest in GIS and spatial data analysis. And it was through my work at GSafety that I realised a demand for GIS specialists. As I wanted to develop myself professionally and have enjoyed working with spatial data and environmental projects, I resolved to develop myself in the GIS field after my contract with GSafety ends.
However, the COVID pandemic corrected those plans. In many ways, accelerating them. After all the lockdowns in China and abroad, the business realities for GSafety changed dramatically, and the work on overseas projects was greatly reduced. In addition, my wife could not return to Beijing as the Chinese government shut down the borders to all foreigners and for most of 2020, I have not seen Veronika, which was hard. Considering all of the above, I have decided to terminate my contract with GSafety, and we agreed to end our cooperation in August 2020.

I moved to Moscow in September 2020 because my wife was from there. It still amazes me that despite growing up in different environments, we developed very similar values and have similar worldviews. Since we met, Veronika has been an immensely supportive and loving person, and she is a significant part of my life.
As the hybrid war between Russia and Ukraine has been ongoing since 2014, and I could see firsthand that Russia has moved in the wrong direction, I never intended to stay in Moscow. I used my time there to develop myself and make my GIS dream closer. I have completed several online courses related to GIS and programming. I have also taken some tests and applied to a handful of universities in Britain to develop my GIS career. We moved out of Russia in September 2021 and have determined never to live in a totalitarian state again.
Coursera. Fundamentals of GIS
Coursera. GIS data formats, design and quality
Esri. ArcGIS Pro Essential Workflows
Esri. Spatial Analysis with ArcGIS Pro

At the university of Manchester, I have had an incredible access to the latest developments in the Geographical Information Science and I have greatly enjoyed my studies. I worked on various projects involving LiDAR and SAR data, Google Earth Engine, ArcGIS software, QGIS, Flood Modeler, SNAP software, etc. I have greatly improved my command of R, JavaScript, Python and SQL. As the program was quite programming and data heavy I have decided to programming skills to … For my final dissertation at the university, I developed a full-stack multimedia location-based web application to connect people and places through personal stories and street art. I used open-source JavaScript libraries (leaflet.js and turf.js), as well as HTML and CSS, to make the app interactive and engaging. I relied on the Python Flask framework to deploy the app and enable users to add independently created location-based content. SQLAlchemy was used to add and manage multimedia content and spatial data in the SQLite database. The web app is available at: Manc Stories I recommended accessing it through a smartphone as it was built for mobile devices.
